snippet.title: The cake is the truth: Chef whips up video game recipes
snippet.description: The Gourmet Gaming blog plucks foods from video games out of their virtual worlds and offers them as real-life recipes. Think Cluckin' Bell Fowl Burger from Grand Theft Auto IV and Bioshock Finkton's Baked Beans.

snippet.title: Turkey welcomes back Twitter
snippet.description: The ban has officially been lifted, a Turkish government official confirms to Reuters.

snippet.title: Cook up IFTTT recipes on your iPad
snippet.description: With version 2.0 of the popular iOS app, iPad users can now create and manage their if/thens. Plus: push notifications!

snippet.title: Wolfgang Puck Pressure Oven
snippet.description: Packing the benefits of pressure cooking into a countertop oven is a pretty clever idea. Chef Puck's oven isn't perfect, and at $249 it isn't for everyone, but crafty home cooks will nonetheless appreciate its performance.

snippet.title: Two anonymous Twitter accounts blocked in Turkey
snippet.description: Accounts linked to the spread of government corruption allegations appeared blocked less than a week after the social network agreed to shutter some accounts.

snippet.title: Twitter agrees to shutter some accounts, Turkey says
snippet.description: The company will not, however, open an office in Turkey just yet, despite requests from the Turkish government.

snippet.title: Google: Turkey is blocking our DNS service
snippet.description: Google says Turkish Internet service providers have set up servers that "masquerade" as Google's public DNS service.

snippet.title: Create, manage recipes with IFTTT for iPhone
snippet.description: You can now automate your digital life from your iPhone using the official IFTTT app.

snippet.title: Thanksgiving in space: Irradiated turkey on the menu
snippet.description: Six astronauts on the International Space Station will enjoy a tweaked version of the traditional Thanksgiving menu.

snippet.title: Turkey approves legislation to block Internet sites
snippet.description: Passed by Turkey's parliament, the bill would allow the government to cut off access to any site without the need for court approval, says the Wall Street Journal.
